title: Christian Nationality is a threat to freedom, plain and simple

author: Wonderful-Article126
text:
Identify a specific group and quote them saying they want to amend the constitution to remove the establishment clause.

You cannot do it because it didn’t happen.

You also show you don’t understand what laws are when you act outraged at the idea that we would create laws based on moral standards.

That is the definition of what a law is - the legal enforced expression of what society has decided are the moral standards.

There is no such thing as law without morals. The two are inextricably linked in concept.

And you don’t get to decide where people derive their moral standards from in a democratic election.

For you to try to wag your finger and tell Christians that their morality is not allowed to influence their voting is the ultimate hypocrisy on your part as you are effectively trying to enforce an atheistic theocracy. The same thing communists do.

author: ShafordoDrForgone
text:
>Identify a specific group and quote them saying they want to amend the constitution to remove the establishment clause.

*“I’m tired of this separation of church and state junk — that’s not in the constitution. It was in a stinking letter and it means nothing like they say it does,” Boebert said, earning a round of applause from the audience.*

*“The reason we had so many overreaching regulations is because the church complied,” she said. “The church is supposed to direct the government. The government is not supposed to direct the church. That is not how our founding fathers intended it.”*

​

>There is no such thing as law without morals.

Exactly what part of Daylight Savings Time is in any religious text or philosophical moral code?

​

>For you to try to wag your finger and tell Christians that their morality is not allowed to influence their voting is the ultimate hypocrisy on your part as you are effectively trying to enforce an atheistic theocracy.

Who said anything about barring morality from influencing a citizen's voting?

The only laws that the government should make are those that govern disputes between people. I know of no atheist trying to insist that two consenting men have sex. Plenty of laws on the books that were meant to arrest them if they do

author: Acceptable-Ad8922
text:
As a lawyer, I can assure you that the EC is being eroded to effectively be written out of the Constitution, at least in the way it has been understood for pretty much forever. Of course they aren’t outright calling for its removal—they don’t need to. They have a sympathetic SCOTUS.

Your morality diatribe is similarly flawed. Laws affecting everyone should not be based on a singular, rather narrow moral code. You’ve tacitly acknowledged this: “law is . . . what *society has decided* are the moral standards.” The problem with Christian Nationalists and many evangelicals is that they wish to impart their narrow, often minority position upon people. Marriage equality and abortion access are majority positions, but you wouldn’t think that based on the way many “Christian “ politicians speak and vote.

Lastly, once you’ve pulled the “communist card,” you’ve lost.

author: Wonderful-Article126
text:
You admit no one is trying to change the constitution. So you have created a strawman position attached to a strawman group for no other purpose than the craft a false narrative trying to demonize ordinary Christians for the crime of voting consistent with their morals.

You are a hypocrite for believing you are entitled to vote consistent with your morals but Christians are not, for no other reason than because you deem their views to be in the minority.

That is not how democracy works - You do not get to judge who is allowed to vote based on whether or not you find their views acceptable.

If Christian morals truly were such a minority as you claim then you wouldn’t have to fear free and fair elections.

You show yourself for what you are: an ideological tyrant and authoritarian atheist who doesn’t want to be subject to democratic processes in imposing your morals on others.

This manufactured media narrative of “christian nationalism” is a transparent attempt to try to intimidate and shame Christians into the closet so they will stop publicly advocating for people to vote consistent with Christian morals.

You are the minority trying to use force to get your way. If you were not the minority you would not need to use these coordinated media intimidation tactics based on strawman lies.

If you don’t want to be compared to communists then stop acting like them.

author: Wonderful-Article126
text:
> https://www.nytimes.com/2022/09/04/us/politics/constitutional-convention-republican-states.html

Calling for a convention does not prove your claim that they are calling for a convention for the express purpose of removing the establishment clause.

You cannot quote any group or leader as wanting to abolish the establishment clause.

You should not need that basic logic explained to you about why your link failed to prove your claim.

You either lack the ability to form basic logical connections or you are intentionally making dishonest arguments. The later makes you guilty of the logical fallacy of arguing in bad faith.

If your claim of being a lawyer were true then it would not be surprising if you are comfortable with making knowingly dishonest arguments in an effort to win an argument. That might be allowed in a courtroom but it isn’t allowed in a logical debate.

If you thought you were making an honest and valid argument then it does not bode well for your career as a lawyer because a strong grasp of logic is necessary to be a good one.

> Nobody said anything about voting

You cannot point to any particular action American Christians have done which you find objectionable other than the fact that you don’t like who they are voting into power.

So the only implication of your screed against Christians is you don’t want them voting consistent with their morals.

You cannot point to anything else they have done and give any logical reason why it is objectionable.

But voting consistent with your morals is not a crime, it is not unconstitutional, it is not immoral, it is not unethical - it is the very basis upon which our voting system functions.

You do it. You expect other atheists to do it too. So you are a hypocrite for acting like Christians are somehow wrong for doing the same thing.

What is it called when your side gets to have a voice by the other side doesn’t? Authoritarianism. As in Fascism or Communism.

Like most hardcore leftists in America today you are an authoritarian at heart. You want to silence your opposition by force because you cannot win on the battleground of ideas.

Getting into a tit for tat over democrat crimes at polling places is not relevant or necessary when your statements and behavior already demonstrate that you resent Christians for doing nothing other than for voting consistent with their morals and act like they have committed some kind of crime by doing so.

If you resent Christians for voting consistent with their morals and want to try to use the bludgeon of the corporate media weapon system to intimidate or shame them into not doing that (by making up scary sounding labels for them and lumping them in with nazi groups and the KKK - the leftist go-to tactic of just calling everyone that disagrees with them racist),  then you cannot claim to honestly be concerned about voting integrity - you are only concerned with your side winning at any cost.

author: Wonderful-Article126
text:
> You said "You admit no one is trying to change the constitution." and I provided evidence of people who are trying to change the constitution

Logical fallacy, strawman. The context of my statement was you claiming people wanted to remove the establish clause from the constitution.

You do not prove your claim that people want to remove the establishment clause of the constitution by pointing to someone who wants to change the constitution but does not want to remove the establishment clause.

The fact that you think your links is proof of your claim therefore shows you either lack basic abilities to form sound logical connections in making arguments, or you are being intentionally dishonest by making an argument you know is fallacious and hoping you just don’t get called out on it.


> Here's your quote from elected official Republican U.S. Rep. Lauren Boebert said: "The church is supposed to direct the government. The government is not supposed to direct the church."

That is not expressing a desire to remove the establishment clause from the constitution.

Firstly, because you fail to understand the the “church” in the Bible is just a word for the body of believers in Jesus.

Secondly, because you fail to apply the proper context of that quote which is that the government has no business telling the church what they are to do but because we are a democratically elected government the people have business telling the government what to do.

With 63% of the American population estimated to identify ad Christian, and our system is governed by majority vote, it is an accurate statement to say that the church (the body of Christian followers as a whole) are the ones who tell the government what to do. And the government does not get to tell them what to do.

The former is how a democratically elected republic works.

The later is how authoritarianism works.

> You keep talking about voting and OP is talking about barring government from respecting an establishment of religion as stated in the Constitution.

You couldn’t prove anyone wants to actually remove the establishment clause.

So what are these so-called “christian nationalists” doing that has you so upset?

You can’t point to anything they have done other than simply vote for candidates that are consistent with their moral values.

And if you are against letting Christians vote consistent with their morals, while you feel free to do it as an atheist, then that just makes you an authoritarian fascist/communist who wants to silence political opposition by force.

You cannot even coherently define what that term “christian nationalist” means.

It is just a demonizing label the corporate media has invented to slap onto any Christian that they find politically difficult to deal with.

What they are really saying is that if you actually believe your faith and advocate people vote consistent with it’s morals then you are wrong and must be demonized until you go in the closet.

But if you are one of the “good” christians who agrees with what the world says is true and keeps quiet, then we won’t call you a racist all over corporate media.
